7Q3FW_Z1ZKIL1GJ-RcWwyA.text: We stopped in at Aladin a few weeks ago. We were in the mood for a curry and Aladin had good reviews. We had to wait and no one was trying to entice us with free booze or poppadums, but it was worth it for the food. It's good food at a good price, and they gave us a coupon to use at the off-license down the street since it's BYOB.

gE5juQqCO4E8yEa1nfnpTA.text: Brick Lane is a great place for some delicious authentic Indian food.  Walk up and down this area, and you'll find deals upon deals being offered to you, trying to lure you into this or that restaurant.  A round of drinks free.  BYOB (or whatever alcohol of your choice) without any fees.  Appetizers for half off.  Deals, right?Aladdin's host, owner, promoter, whatever he was offered us a discount on our entire meal and beverages.  The food was spicy when promised to be spicy.  The yogurt drink calmed the fire in our throats (and tummies!). And we left the restaurant stuffed and blissfully happy with our food.

nlZfiq7DgCQ4sbU2dbEyBQ.text: I've never felt so tense in a restaurant!! I brought a friend here last night to relax and catch up after a long day's work. From beginning to end we were harassed by the waiters. Poppadum, poppadum? No thanks - give me a second to look at the menu. Under pressure, I thought I'd ask to order starters to buy ourselves time to chose our mains. No - we're too busy - the restaurant is fully booked - we were told by a very rude waiter. I was appalled. My friend had to convince me not to storm out. The food came, then was removed by the waiter who swished the plate fishing around for lamb - "OK - it's fine. I thought it was chicken..." - not the nicest the feeling and obviously no apology. The food was bland. I did enjoy the peshwari nan though - it had a perfect texture and a very pleasant taste. The rice had gone a little hard from sitting out for too long - I had sylheti lamb which I thought was really undercooked and the tarka daal was not good. Our plates were removed and the bill thrown onto the table. A minute later, I saw a pair of terrified eyes on my friend's face. When I turned around I saw the waiter making signs at her to pay up... Just don't go.

LnWOtLE2C_5XmBiGrUjvYQ.text: Why Why Why cant there be amazing UK curry in the bay area? Out of our 3 nights in London we spent two dinners on brick lane. This was our second place. We walked up and down the street talking to the guys hawking places asking who would make the spiciest curry! We settled on Aladin. We walked in and sat down, and a guy comes over to us and whispers "you got alcohol"...my bf was like "um no" we thought we were in like major trouble with the brick lane mafia or something. Come to find out they dont sell alcohol but they allow you to BYOB, AWESOME! So the bf went down the street to a corner store and brought back some Cobras/King Fishers. We pretty much let the waiter order for us...told him we wanted SPICY! It was soooo good we had the Chicken Dansak and Chicken Naga. Cant wait to go back!

CNersvpVVPSI3J7Eg8K8Kw.text: My daughter's birthday week-end and she wanted a trip down the smoke. Saturday we visited the excellent Camden Market and then on to Greenwich. An overnight stay at the Hilton Docklands and then out to Amy Child's Salon. Back in the afternoon and to Madame Tussaud's, finally as a thank you to dad she let me visit the famous Brick Lane for the first time. The concentration of restaurants in Brick Lane is impressive and even on a Sunday the parking wasn't easy but we eventually struck lucky in a side street. We walked nearly the length of Brick Lane and ran the highly irritating gauntlet of the persistent touts and their offers. We finally chose the Aladin for no good reason. Perhaps we were persuaded by the Best in the World banner and it did look popular, perhaps it was because we didn't want to have to fight our way passed the touts back up the road, or was it the 20% discount offered? We couldn't get into the Aladin but were found a table in the adjacent Raznul restaurant instead. The decor is basic and a few repairs and tidying up wouldn't go amiss. Thinking this wasn't the Aladin and perhaps just a relation we nearly left, however we were assured it shared the same kitchen and after all it's the food that matters. Our waiter wasn't overly friendly, he seemed to be impatient which was surprising considering the restaurant was 3/4 empty. It was after 8.00pm and with a drive back to Dudley to look forward to we unfortunately had to go straight into the mains. To sum up briefly, the mains were good with the sundries being just ok. We had no complaints but likewise there was nothing special either. My opinion is that the Aladin is a typical balti house, certainly not bad but we couldn't find anything very good or different about it either plus they don't do deserts apart from kulfi. More importantly they also don't do itemised bills and we were overcharged plus we then had to ask for our discount. Unsurprisingly my conclusion is that it probably isn't the best curry house in the world indeed I would be extremely surprised if it was the best in Brick Lane.

InAwRJIJzJLvXADeMBqt7Q.text: I was told not expect much of the service when coming here but the food would be worth it. They were right about the service, although I can't fault their enthusiasm, unfortunately, however, they were not so spot on about the food. For me this Indian was average; the lamb was just a tad tough and undercooked for my liking, possibly anyone's liking. Granted though, it is still a good little spot to go when wondering brick lane; take your wine and beer with you as this baby is completely BYO.

I9qqpjiPFq3bXd6wEo754A.text: An outstanding menu let down by shambolic (although resolutely polite) service. To be fair, we arrived at the height of the busy period, loaded with our lager and lady petrol (white wine) as they do not have a licence. Once inside, the remains of the baying mob the other side of the glass front waiting for their table were not as distracting as I had expected, but what could have been a cracking meal experience was marred by chaotic organisation. If these guys got their act together and got people in and out with a bit more efficiency they'd get twice the business as the curries are damn fine.

kTf-eXme4LGtpiEC79J_AQ.text: A terrible experience. I booked a table for two for 9pm but on arrival we were told we would have to wait 10 minutes for some customers to leave. We waited patiently outside in the pouring rain for over 40 minutes after being told continuously it would be ready in 10 minutes. We finally got a table and then waited 30 minutes for anyone to take our order after which we were asked to move to a smaller table as they could squeeze four people onto ours. In fact, during the course of this awful experience we were asked to move tables THREE TIMES in one hour. The food was okay (the starters were cold) but not exceptional. I asked for the bill which took 15 minutes, I left cash on the table and after 20 minutes waiting for my change to come back (over £5.00), we gave up and made an escape. Utterly disappointing. And some of the staff were very rude.

6fdQCyMCRXJJtiFl_2WXqg.text: tense, pushed in and pushed out. we had two sets of cutlery between 3 and when i asked for another the waiter seemed 'put out' by this!!?? stood by our table when we were finishing our dinner so that we would shove of quicker. very rude. dont ruin your night by going here!

Rd4Hsx1pUUXK9Yi48BT2jg.text: Absolutely disappointing. The palak paneer was sweet?! I used to frequent the place ages ago and just visited. Had many fond memories of post pub curries with friends. The shambolic cooking was heart breaking. Never again. Especially embarrassing as I had talked it up to my companions.

Fglp06tNyGBM2BXAKpKqNw.text: Decent Curry.Thought the service was a tad sub-par. I don't like being rushed while I order/eat and the wait staff was definitely not as cordial as they should be - considering how aggressive their barker was.Barker: I'll give him credit that he had a different "sales pitch" - He takes you down the street and says he's giving a voucher for drinks to bring into the restaurant. It's of course a sham as I've realized that all Indian spots on Brick Lane pretty much come out to the same ol tired "20% discount". It's a sham for tourists but sometimes it's fun haggling with them.Honestly, not the best on Brick Lane.

DtVy5SddhGcmRTvgOTlLFA.text: We came to Brick Lane looking for a fantastic Indian restaurant we'd been to a year earlier, but alas it was no longer there.  So we wandered up and down the lane looking for a new one that was a) crowded, and b) nobody outside harassing passers by.   We found that at Aladin.  Glowing references on the window convinced us even more that this must be the hot place to go.  We were wrong.Unlike the experience others had, the service was actually pretty good.  But the food was somewhere between poor and average, the prices high considering the tiny portions (smallest naan ever, small pilau rice, hardly any lamb in my Lamb Dupiaza).  My lamb dish when done right has finely cut, long cooked onions that are sweet and make for a rich sauce.  Here they were hacked pieces, barely cooked, their ratio to meat literally 5 to 1.  Not awful, but not something I'd ever want again.  My girlfriend's Chile Chicken Masala  bore no resemblance to any we'd experienced before, and not in a good way.  It was bright red and hugely coconut flavored giving it an overly sweet, and like mine, heavy handed execution.  Worst of all was biting into the searingly hot raw chilis which they had used to spice up the dish, rather than incorporating spice heat correctly in the cooking.I don't know which is the best Indian on Brick Lane, but I can guarantee it isn't this one.

4_E5z5uUPL85UX_fpAYpVQ.text: Came to this fun neighborhood for great shopping.  The whole street has a fun vibe of great Indian food with aggressive hosts and BOYB rules.We were referred to this restaurant, and surprised when the host tried to bring us in next door.  They said most of the restaurants are connected and all many related.  That's too bad because our food was just mediocre at best.  Gimmicky, and cheaply done.  Just not into coconut rice that's not made with coconut milk, but with too much oil and rice that looks like Fruit Loops.

IdPt8MfpsTMDGW5nTbyEiA.text: The photogenic BrickLane of East London seems to be the only place where walls are encouraged to be artistically manipulated. Denim &  Leather jacketeers pounce down on street steps, puffing away on their fags, the assortment of Indian restaurants from left to right gets any appetite brewing, the slew of vintage clothing shops and the variety of world culture's makes Brick Lane a sort of pleasure dome for curious eyes. With so many restaurants to choose from, and me being the only yelper to yelp about them,luck factor is all I had in determining the right one (I'm obvi against referring to any other form of reviews) so I took my chances with Aladin. After reading about the approval from the prince or some blah blah thing on the window, I sat down.First things first:"Do you have Cobra?" (my favorite British/Indian beer)"No." a despondent response came my way."Do you have beer?" I mean, if they don't have Cobra..."No, we are royal." Right, well then...the waiter basically hated me from then on and although my Balti Lamb was a 7.5/10 the service was about a 5. Even though a 7.5/10 dish equates to a 10/10 to American Indian Food, I guarantee you I won't be returning to Aladin ever again.

photos.caption: Photo of Aladin - London, United Kingdom. Curry & Rice

OEMW8Op2-Z-n94_EPdm4Ag.text: I quite like the food here, but then again, I'm no expert on Bangladeshi cuisine. But come here in a group, especially mid-week, and you can haggle an absolute *bargain*. The staff are all really friendly and remember my name, though you have to make sure they don't slip in anything like Poppadums onto the table when you've not Negotiated for them to be included. But for what you can get for 10 pounds, and how long you can sit around and chat afterwards for (especially with my habit of arriving at 10pm), this'll always be a useful little place for me.

W6ODN3ui-WLIkW2GhCQbRg.text: Food was good, service was pitiful. The servers were totally rude when it came time for us to leave. Really ended our night with a sour note. Won't be back.

jJ8lJMkkYBfgDE_X9iIRiQ.text: Have been slowly making my way through the curry house on Brick Lane and went here one night due to recommendations of others. Sadly disappointed as the only thing I really liked about Aladin was the BYO. On initial arrival our group was promised a 'special deal,' however when it came time to pay the bill, all of a sudden our special deal had vanished and in its place numerous extra costs! Very sad as the curry was good, not great and the service when also good. Nothing extremely negative here but will not feel guilty moving onto the next curry house on my next Brick Lane visit.

tQQ4UDLCQROzrmZCGr2bLg.text: Price quality for Indian hard to beat in London! I've been many times and simply love the food and lively sometimes chaotic service, incl dudes at the door pulling customers in. Two staters, two mains, rice and loads of naan bread for 25 quid!

p1oHDjdKVpHZHJ9DWS9cFw.text: So, Allow us to be the odd ones out here. I googled reviews on this place which as you can read..are pretty impressive. We noticed the "special" in the window so we walked in. After sitting we were handed a menu which did not reflect the same menu/prices that were in the window. Call it "bate and switch" or whatever, restaurants would fare much better if they were only honest and fair! So we ordered 1 full meal from the special and one regularly priced. When ordering, we all said we did not want highly spicy dishes. When ordering  we were assured the dishes would be made to our taste. WRONG! They were almost inedible!  Next problem,  after 50 minutes of waiting the food came. We believe they make you wait so you buy papadoms which cost .75 pence each and then they charge extra for the chutney. When the food eventually came each and every dish was so overly spicy hot that they were practicaly inedible! If not for the price which wasn't terrible but still at tourist level, we would have not forced the food down and would have walked out! Please people, don't believe all the reviews and awards restaurants boast about!!! What happen to wanting returning customers?? What happened to customer service?

4IfFmt1NaDQxLBy-SbksZQ.text: Wow, this place is terrible. We came in a few nights ago to try what a few places had listed as the best tikka masala on brick lane. What a joke! The absolute worst Indian food I have tasted in my life, and in all honesty I have never had Indian food that is not palatable. Me and my group got tikka masala, lamb rogan, paneer, and vegetable tikka. The tikka masala tasted sweet and syrupy (I kid you not), and we even asked for it spicy. The paneer was bland and tasteless, there was absolutely no care taken with it.  The only passable dish was the lamb rogan, and even with that, the tomatoes were barely cooked (which is not something you normally find with indian food). Never ever again, even with the 20 percent discount. I find it necessary to mention that despite the bad food, the staff is pleasant and courteous.

yI_JMGwIpeALDxXgI_z8NA.text: My friend and I were exploring Brick Lane last week, when we realised we were hungry and ready for an early dinner. We walked past a number of curry restaurants, complete with men outside attempting to seduce us into their stores - oh, by the way, guys? Saying 'hi' in Japanese to two Chinese girls isn't going to work in your favour - and settled on Aladin, mainly due to the good prices and the list of accolades posted in the windows.The place was pretty busy when we arrived at 4:30, yet we were seated and attended to fairly quickly. Neither one of us had any idea what to order at first (the menu isn't particularly descriptive, so our waiter kindly fielded our questions), but I ended up getting the chicken dansak with plain naan, while my friend had the chicken ceylon. Both dishes were tasty, though for a 'medium hot' dish, mine definitely could have been spicier. All in all, though, if you have a hankering for solid curry that won't break the bank, Aladin is a good place to check out.

Dz9mP8HoAWvQY9Cduk-udg.text: Brick Lane is the most popular place in East London for curries. Every step taken down the Street is littered with PR types begging you to come in and taste their wares; offering 'discount' off the menu (the menu already shows the price with the discount, so not particularly exclusive!) but this isn't to say that their food is any good. (although some is) Aladins. What a diamond in the rough. You'd be forgiven for thinking it was crap, mainly because it looks crap. But once you step inside and are greeted by the warm, friendly staff and the fragrances reach your nose all will become clear. The decor and lighting have a lot to be desired, but the food is divine. Tender meat, beautiful spices and perfectly sized portions. Fresh Naan and lovely rice are great accompaniments as well as the extra tasty lime pickle (to be taken with poppadoms, of course!). Oh yeah, and it's bring your own booze. Get in!

photos.caption: Photo of Aladin - London, United Kingdom

XJI2zYL9slQmQIQ4E3fyhA.text: I love Indian food, so much so, that I'm forgiving of most places that serve mediocre food.  But this one merited a review if only for the fact that we went out of our way to eat there -- and we're HIGHLY DISSATISFIED!  The first sign that we were going to have an inauthentic experience is the fact that there were only Caucasians eating there.  Not one local Indian?  The chicken Tikka Masala, spinach and even naan tasted really I characteristically sweet?  Wrong.  Off actually?  It's a shame since the evening started with fantastic mango lassi's and savory vegetable simosas (made with philo dough).  In an effort to salvage the meal, I ordered a tandoori chicken, which I thought was ok, but my co-patrons disagreed.  And I should admit that the service was good, but not good enough to eat there.  SKIP this joint if you're looking for good Indian food.

psSVut9RyY9_gjau1efS4Q.text: The place had good reviews and that was why we chose this place. The food came very late, when we were about to give up. The food was bland, dull, worse than a Sainsbury's microwaveable "Indian" and four times more expensive. We were a party of six, none of us ate very much of it.  We agreed, unanimously: not going there again.

oVnjen7Pwl49IHX6FRMGrQ.text: There are a lot of Indian restaurants to try on Brick Lane, all promising you the best curry you've ever tasted....I think Aladin is the only one that has ever actually lived up to these expectations! When we arrived there was already quite a substantial queue outside but the head waiter got us a table in the 5 minutes it took for us to go to the shop next door and buy our alcohol (its a BYO restaurant). As soon as we were seated, he recommended us a few of their most famous dishes and within 5 minutes we were tucking in! The bengali Tikka curry was delicious, as was tandoori chicken and the vegetable naan. We all really enjoyed our food and the whole restaurant had a great atmosphere. So if you are on Brick Lane, make this place your first port of call!

ZD-nCtlXFVQizbqVC8b52g.text: I don't know how it has such a high rating - it definitely doesn't deserve it! The atmosphere was good but the food was average at best. No better than the other average curry houses along Brick Lane. And the service - pretty appalling. As soon as we finished our food the unashamedly asked us to leave so they could sit another table. Talk about being treated like crap! I would definitely avoid this place.

hmhXpJyXJIFpeT38osyDzw.text: The food was brilliant. I had the chicken Sag and it was very tasty indeed. My mum had the Lamb Dansak and that was also very well cooked and gorgeous tasting. We didn't get any special deals outside though which is unusual for Brick Lane! We also got charged an extra few pounds which was cheeky as the bill didn't have a summary of each item just a total and we calculated it and even with a service charge added on they still over charged us! Imagine if they're doing that to everyone! cheeky!

W8iVgcSk4zMXtCz_veGZ4A.text: A last-minute Twitter shout-out resulted in tons of great Brick Lane curry house recommendations, and we opted for this one because of its location at the right end of the strip for our next destination. Having battled through the gauntlet of restaurant staff trying to entice you through their doorways - one of whom took one look at me and decided that screaming "TWO BOTTLES OF FREE WINE!!!" in my face would be the best approach (to be fair, he's not far off) - we made it to Aladin and were promised a £7.95 special offer. This included a starter, a curry and a rice or naan bread, plus a free drink. It was only when I looked at the drinks 'menu' that I realised it was BYO. Bugger. But we couldn't be arsed to go out to fetch booze so we happily made do with soft drinks. Despite what I've read in other reviews about the service I thought it was pretty good, and certainly friendly. My paneer and spinach pancake starter was huuuge - and delicious - but sadly it totally filled me up before my main course. So although I wasn't really that impressed with my curry (can't remember which one I chose now), it could have been because I simpy had no appetite left. This was only my second visit to a Brick Lane curry house, and it was certainly a better experience than the first. Then again, I can't really remember too much about the first time if I'm completely honest (one of those nights...). So if you're heading to Brick Lane and want a recommendation for a decent curry house which won't set you back more than a tenner a head, you could do a lot worse than Aladin. Just remember to bring your own...

BHadJlePvOvt3VGR0qoOfg.text: Anytime I am in London I come here for Indian food.  I have never had a bad meal here.  The place was / hopefully still is BYOB.  There is a liquor store just down the street on the same side as the restaurant.  The service is fast, the price is affordable (even with the quid to USD conversion) and you will go away full.  They will destroy you with spice if you ask.  I witnessed this happen to my buddy first hand.  Go here for great Indian food.

QNFAM4y9ZJwbyU4a-tXx1g.text: Awful. I've never tasted so much sugar in Indian food before. The Chicken blast tasted like burnt sugar and the butter chicken tasted slightly better but still sugary. The sag paneer, sugary. The cauliflower chana, sugary. Even the veg biryani, sugary!  Yuck yuck yuck!

Hgshc9PSiQyru8AI0jzNxg.text: Jeez Us. Bricklane is Little Bangladesh .... and man is the food great. There must be 50 Bangladeshie restaurants in 3-4 blocks. All of which say they have the best curries.Well Aladin has amazing curries. From mild, medium and hot....all were very flavorful. The meat was not cheap. The chicken was really tasty. The lamb was not fatty. Their naan was warm light and buttery...perfect for sopping up all the tasty curry sauce.The service was spot on. The restaurant is clean. The setting is nice.What more can one ask????

pm0fiuTEMGcGo2xPuXKS3A.text: Poped into that nicely quiet place on our way back from Brick Lane. To be fair, neither of us expected the food to be that great for such a reasonable price. A Chicken curry, one big Chef's specialty : chicken marinated in a creamy minty spinach sauce, plain nan bread, some mushroom pilau rice & two juices for less than £30. As much as the food deserves 5 stars, the service do not even deserves one. The only available waiter was absolutely not helpful : my coat was still unbutton that I've been asked on & on for a starter or a thing to share. Then we had to signal him a few time to pass the order or even to pay the bill. The waiter was just to busy talking with a mate on the opposite side of the room. But, let's be grown ups here. The food is really great and I will definitely go back there again, and guys, give them a chance ;)

photos.caption: Photo of Aladin - London, United Kingdom. Plain nan & mushroom pilau rice
Photo of Aladin - London, United Kingdom. Chef's speciality : chicken in a minty spinach sauce
Photo of Aladin - London, United Kingdom. Chicken curry

_6R6NserP58Lh7XzxSrj7A.text: So bad.. I'm not even sure why I am giving the extra star.. Probably because it's a food review and I love food... But this was nothing beyond decent. Came here with a large group very excited to try apparently an award winning restaurant.. We waited about 30 mins to order and didn't receive our food til an hour later!The service was horrible as I see almost all the other reviews also mentioned... Not just slow, but extremely rude. Thinking our food was going to be good we stuck around but with the fact we were starving and it only tasted decent kinda means it's not great at all. Won't be back. Maybe even wait outside if friends want to go!

o5TF1BNkunbDJUuQPrRL-g.text: I came to Aladin with a friend visiting London who really wanted some Indian food on Brick Lane.  We went online and checked out places and their reviews and this establishment stood out.  I have to admit, I'm not a big fan of Indian cuisine, but I did have a very pleasant meal here.  We were seated immediately and had some tap water to start.  I had the chicken tikka masala and it was really rich and filling, along with some garlic nomm, which was perfect for dipping in the sauce.  We also ordered rice on the side (one serving is more than enough to share between two people!).  What I also liked about this place is that unlike most restaurants on Brick Lane, the staff isn't out on the street hustling you to try their food.  That was really refreshing.  I'll remember that plus the really rich meal I've had next time a friend wants some Indian food on Brick Lane!

EEEvHdDcz6yHQmrIRMn9-A.text: Food was great, service by Bodz was excellent. We'll definitely eat there if the opportunity is given.My wife had the chicken rezala and it had great flavor and was mildly spiced.  I ordered the kebabish jalfreezi which was very spicy - 4 on a 5 scale I would estimate.  Very, very good.Restaurant was somewhat loud but there was a somewhat rowdy group of guys in there so maybe that explains it.

KAWv03KYWiM2_oBmEFWVhw.text: Came here with a big group a while back. I actually really enjoyed this lamb curry that I had (I don't remember what it was - it was a 'chef special').The pros: - They take large group reservations and gave us a discount off the total bill for booking in advance- Massive menu, reasonable prices, and food was good- BYOB, no corkage feesThe cons:- Service was the biggest issue. For a group of 10 people, they should have blocked out at LEAST an hour and a half. We were rushed out of there in less than one hour. Towards the end they were hassling us and telling us that they needed the table, before people were even finished eating. This is an unacceptable way to manage a restaurant.- They tried to pull a fast one on us re: the group booking discount. We looked at the bill at the end and it wasn't there, and we had to flag down the waiter and ask them for it. What?!? Did they think we were not going to notice?? I thought this was a very skeevy move.- They only take one or two credit cards per bill. Come on guys... this isn't technological limitation, everyone knows how those portable card machines work. This is laziness.I wish I could give this place more stars because the food was really quite good. The horrendous service killed our experience.

4SOTAREEtzE8bCu-18gdfA.text: This was the second restaurant that I've tried on Brick Lane, and I would say the quality of the food was on par with the first.I ordered a mix of Chicken and Lamb Mardas with Garlic Rice. It was exactly what I was looking for in a south Asian dish. It was fairly hot as it stated on the menu. The madras curry sauce was excellent with the rice.The service was attentive, but the waiter was a bit pushy and quite unhelpful when I was ordering.

1H9ulvXwHA1Ngh79iGcMCw.text: One of the key tips I learned before coming to Brick Lane was to avoid the curry houses where they solicit (read: pressure) people to come in.  Aladin is definitely not one of those places.  Actually, it's so popular, that they have a guy out front to keep people out! We took a risk and went down after 7PM on a Saturday night with no reservations.  Even though the place was packed, we only waited about 15 minutes.  The guy out front was really good about managing the waiting patrons and preventing people from sneaking in.  We were seated next door in Nazrul, which is owned by Aladin and has the Aladin menu (the two restaurants are physically connected inside as well).   I had heard that their King Prawn Biryani was really good, so I ordered that, while my husband ordered the Chicken Kurma, a coconut curry dish.  We also got some Peshwari Nan.  Everything was great.  I really liked the biryani - a very flavorful, mild dish with plenty of prawn.  And it came with an outrageously delicious vegetable curry.  My husband was pleased with his curry, which was rich in flavor, not too much heat.  Service was good, more so once the order was in.The overall experience was fine, until a huge 30+ group of twenty-somethings came in, filling over half the restaurant.  Not only were they insanely loud, but they had brought champagne, which upon opening exploded in an arc over their table and spraying the family next to us.  No acknowledgment or apology for the family - they just went on being rambunctious and oblivious.  Fortunately we were well into our meal, but we kind of rushed to finish so we could get out of there.  Not really the fault of the restaurant, but still put a damper on the end.All in all, I can definitely say Aladin has earned its great reputation.

photos.caption: Photo of Aladin - London, United Kingdom. From top, clockwise: Chicken Kurma, Vegetable Curry, King Prawn Biryani
Photo of Aladin - London, United Kingdom

qP4CMux9wGwOsfo5FgcEUw.text: The majority of the food here is very good and since everyone below has told you what to order I will keep it brief. Here is the one thing you should know if you are planning on eating here and are form someplace other than the UK... As a rule, they put SUGAR in the Chicken Tikka Masala in the UK. Not a little, a lot. Enough that the dish tastes sweet. So, if you don't like sugar in your curry, do not order it. Oh, the saag paneer has sugar in it too. There, now go eat at Aladdin, people are nice and the food is good.

km2HeYjiCDg7sUGZNN1LIQ.text: This is the worst place ever. DO NOT GO HERE! My wife is vegan and she was given a meat samosa and then her second dish had butter. Service by waiter was sometimes ok sometimes he's just not able to understand.

photos.caption: Photo of Aladin - London, United Kingdom. They said 2x this was brown rice. REALLY?!?

mNvAEvpjcCCoBKoM1qVpow.text: I really don't understand the good reviews here. Main dishes literally were gritty with sugar, slow service, they're constantly trying to upsell, 'bati' versions are same as standard versions of dishes but cost 20% more.. I could continue, but you get the point.We went to Sainsbury's right after to try their chicken tikka masala to make sure Brits don't just like their Indian food sugary, and thankfully that hypothesis was proven wrong. Sainsbury's chicken tikka masala isn't good by any means, but it's leagues better (and cheaper) than the sugary slop at Aladdin.

-GC00j_6MlpPsJ6IphYHvQ.text: I went looking for heat, and boy did I find it.Being a white American guy visiting Indian restaurants in England typically means getting served mild food, no matter what you order. I arrived at Aladin with my heart set on the ("exceptionally spicy" according to their online menu) Lamb Tikka Phall, and that's exactly what I ordered. Unfortunately, the wait staff attempted to talk me out of it, and it took my raising my voice before they would take my order.The dish itself was as expected - fiery and flavorful, although not particularly complex or deep in those flavors. I sweated buckets as I knew I would, and was brought extra napkins to wipe up that sweat without my needing to ask.I would have given three stars instead of four, but compared to the three other places around London where I've tried to get a decent curry this week and have been completely let down, these guys rose high above. Not that this was particularly difficult to do...

1bcj_wjltkapDVNDIdoPOA.text: I was a little disappointed by this place. It was voted best balti house in London this past year, so I was so looking forward to eating at this place when I visited. The flavors were fair but I think I ordered wrong. I got  hariyali chicken, which I've had at Indian/Nepali places in the states and it's quite good. My dish came out an unappetizing Christmas green, found no where in nature. The flavor was good but very sweet, and it was so rich that I was only able to eat a small portion of the dish. The chicken, when extracted from the sauce was cooked tandoori style and tasted much better than the sauce. I might try something else here in the future, but I would not re-try or recommend the hariyali.

tHVCsS7AA9Uncyw5u5_pig.text: Food is not so good here and the portions are small. It also takes forever, so don't come if you're in a hurry. Everything we ordered was sweet for some reason -- even the chicken tikka masala and saag paneer! They'll give you a 20% off deal and no corkage BYOB but I'm not sure I'd come back even with those perks. I'd rather spend a little more for better food.

h6rHuLDiDstqk8gWKM2_jw.text: Cloyingly sweet food in a place whose dirty carpets should have served as a warning. My wife's chicken dish had this sweet green sauce redolent of pumpkin pie spices. Now my stomach hurts and I desperately need a pallet cleanser.

7ELtVFjrzlvBurPtNx6K1w.text: The only reason why Aladin gets 2 stars is because of the poppadom.  I ate my weight in poppadom!Unfortunately, our chicken tikka masala was super sweet and not at all to my liking.  we also ordered samosas, but they were nothing like what I was expecting.  They were essentially just small amounts of meat covered in filo dough.  The service was terribly slow and the portions small.We will definitely not be heading back here any time soon.

2D0S_9yJ9useDXevTZ1n4w.text: Prince Charles supposedly loves this place (or did in 1989), which was good enough for me, my boyfriend, my aunt, and uncle when wandering down Brick Lane trying to figure out how on earth to pick a place to have lunch.  It's an incredibly fun street, with delicious smells coming from everywhere and tons of awesome little shops.  Had zero idea where to go so we figured if Aladin was good enough for Prince Charles, it was good enough for us.And it certainly was "good enough," but I suspect not nearly as good as other places we could've gone to on Brick Lane.  They have a big, almost overwhelming menu, which we perused sitting at a windowside table.  It was a mild, sunny day, so the windows were open which was really nice.  I tasted my aunt's chicken biryani which looked lovely and colorful but tasted a bit flat.  My dish didn't even come close to wowing me - Balti Chicken Dansak, it was - and I thought the spices were pretty...I don't know, poorly blended?  Harsh?  Just didn't have the synchronicity of a really wonderful Indian curry where everything tastes harmonious.  Try somewhere else on the Lane!

ND7CJRgbzeM7Y4c_C8cVgQ.text: It was my first experience dining in Brick Lane. My friend chose the restaurant as he had been there before. We were a fairly large group, but they accommodated us throughout the entire evening- never felt rushed to get up and be done! The food was on par with the reputation that it has. Left more than full!

FIXMFn7tNWiZKxuMb1lZEQ.text: Food is at best average. No alcohol licence = no beer!The worst part is the service, overly aggressive Bangladeshi men with absolutely no idea of customer service trying to make money by bringing you items you never order. Had the impression that thought we were tourist, when we are not. I cannot recommend this restaurant,

tr70F3RIE4spKgLjSMtdHw.text: Best Chicken Tikka Masala I've ever had. The Naan bread was huge and soft. I had to stop myself from licking the plate. When I come back to London I'll be eating here every day.

H4CESI2F6pssvb5TCBHqnw.text: Skip it. Tourist trap. The waiters are rude and make fun of DinersNO ALCOHOL. We asked for some wine and after arguing with us for 15 mins,, the waiter went to the liquor store to buy us some cheap ass wine and came back and said it was 15 GBP. Food was crappy.

photos.caption: Photo of Aladin - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Aladin - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Aladin - London, United Kingdom

Uu65Dw5GqERaxEiidhBdVw.text: Food was tasty. Service was friendly and helpful. Price was right. Large menu although haven't a clue what all the dishes were. But I'm not an accomplished Indian foodie!

5jLLsB4zxA5yCHhUvufPDw.text: I dragged my friends to brick lane on a Friday night because I was keen for some British curry. I scoped around online and the general consensus was Aladin is the best curry house in the area. We walked in and were offered a 20% discount and quickly seated to a booth. I was extremely unimpressed by the restaurant. The ambience is dingy, with crappy paintings and dirty booths. They quickly served us oily pappadums with a plate of sauces. The strangest was the mint sauce which was a bright yellow (yuck). I ordered a cauliflower curry and yellow daal. The cauliflower was oily and doused in a flavourless tomato sauce. The daal was loaded with garlic and just not good. The naan we ordered didn't seem to have been cooked in a tandoor and was really not up to standards.When our bill came it didn't include the discount we were offered and we had to remind them to reduce the price. I'm really confused by the high rating as the food is really terrible and the ambience just didn't cut it.

aJ2k9hBNsrBnAbhREAvtQA.text: This restaurant was bustling with customers when I walked in which seemed to be a good sign. Asked for a menu recommendation once I was seated and took the waiter up on the chicken tikka blast (had to order rice separately and regrettably decided to go with coconut rice).Long story short, I paid a total of 24 euros for one of the most sugary meals I've had (including some much needed counteracting water and plain naan). I couldn't even finish half of what was served. The table next to me paid their bill saying it was "really good" so either they ordered something else entirely or were just being undeservedly nice.

QVkrLiSDH2hJgLmGF6mayA.text: Like, yeah. I mean... it was good. Fun atmosphere. Pretty decent service. Allowed us all to be loud and disheveled and obnoxious. And the food... was 'yeah'. Not like ooohhh yeah, just yeah. The lamb with mango was slightly tough, the cheese naan not that cheesy.... In a town like London, where your mission in life is to line the team's stomachs with that perfect blend of carbs and protein before a solid sesh... THIS specific Indian is not really where I would return.

4221ZSUkKjj3T9QfgCJV6A.text: So I was coming from Berlin where the city's Indian food offerings suck. I came here based on the recommendation of a friend, but I was really let down.The food was good, but simply not what you expect from what should be an authentic Indian curry house, but it was rather similar to what I just left in Berlin (well, to be honest it was similar to the better Indian restaurants in Berlin, but still this is London).

ULGwC_uRZ1TVDn-emHbZig.text: I love Indian food and had heard a lot of good things about Aladin, so they had a lot to live up to for me. They didn't disappoint.Brilliant service, amazing food and brilliant value for money. I got onion bhajis, lamb korma and a load of rice for £10. It was a struggle to finish. All of it was incredible, although the bhajis were a highlight. Also I was pretty impressed at how fast they got me through, had to be close to half an hour. I told them I was in a rush and they delivered.

photos.caption: Photo of Aladin - London, United Kingdom. All for 10

5z6brKHWxZ9NejTgdz9oSw.text: Was very excited to go to brick lane but have to say that my experience at this restaurant was very disappointing. They started off by luring us inside by offering us a 15% off discount off of our bill. Inside, we ordered 3 dishes, then we asked for an order of naan bread. When the server asked us how many orders of naan, we asked how many pieces came in one order...he then asked us what discount we received outside. We told him 15% and saw him write 3 on his notepad. Finally after waiting for 30 minutes for our food to come we asked for one order of rice... the waiter came with THREE orders-- one for each of us. Of course, we were charged for the three plates of rice and in the end were not even sure if the 15% discount was applied. There was no way of knowing because the menu had no prices included. How else will you know what is 15% off?Definitely think I was taken advantage of because of my American accent-- I've been here before with a British friend and was treated completely differently. It's also fortunate for Aladin that gratuity comes included... would not have left a tip at all.

8s7TymW_4Jib9qLExFRWoQ.text: Dingy atmosphere. Mediocre service. Average curry. This was the only British curry I tried on my trip, and I didn't enjoy it. You had to order rice separately. The garlic naan was barely flavored. I had to continually ask for water. Will not return.

JRGy1AuslvSinoTn35smog.text: My sister and I were directed to Aladin after a slightly more upscale/trendy Indian restaurant not too far by was fully booked for the evening. I had my reservations upon entering the restaurant -- mostly the loud/BYOB crowd practically spilling out of the restaurant -- but the "bouncer" at the previous restaurant swore by the spot as the most celebrated in London for Indian food. So so happy we stayed to experience the food AND service. Both surprisingly top-notch. Friendliest waiters -- even gave us extra mango/coconut naan (get it!!) on the house AND a discount on the entire meal. We probably were waited on by 3 different servers but each of them were so attentive to our food + experience. Apparently, they just underwent a big management change and are trying to build up a positive reputation for not only food but also service. We had the chef's special -- grilled lamb + grilled chicken marinated and tossed with special sauce, respectively -- and omg I am salivating as i speak about it. Have yet to have a more authentic, flavorful, satisfying Indian meal. Do yourself a favor and go, go go! Such a great and verry filling (wear loose clothing) way to end our trip.

_PYKEHUrTBUzTN25TMeW5w.text: Came in solo. Heard about this place and Bricklane. It's true, there might be a wait, but it's not too bad. If you're touring the city for like I am, you can be patient and savor for the food, which was good. I highly recommend the Aloo Chat Puri's and the Tandoori chicken.  My trip today we're all small plates that also included the Fried Fish and Naan

photos.caption: Photo of Aladin - London, United Kingdom. Before and after for one person. If it wasn't good, the plates would still be full.

mwruy4AAxIptV_2NVrH9FQ.text: This was the worst service, Indian food and quality I have ever experienced. I was shocked by what they served and called food.

8iRQj8LR0WSUWrgrtjvDzA.text: After visiting this curry house on recommendation from a fellow Yelper I was hugely disappointed and given the mixed reviews I'm guessing this place is very much hit and miss.As a solo diner...I was sat opposite a huge party that was somewhat noisy so I would have preferred somewhere quieter. I had also forgotten it was BYOB and I asked if there was any way I could get a glass of wine to which I was told no. Not long after a couple were sat beside me and the waiter offered to buy them drinks at the shop nearby-way to make someone feel unwanted!! The service was pretty terrible and I hadn't even finished my starter before the main arrived. At this point I just felt like I was being rushed so wolfed down my very average curry and unsatisfactory Nan then made a quick exit! I will never return here again and wouldn't recommend it given the other options on Brick Lane and the surrounding area!

qKBjXZhrkK3Yu8iill2SfA.text: Ok. Let's. Be honest. Awful. I came here starving. By the time my food came I was no longer hungry I was so tired. They took easily an hour. And when the food came it was poor. Really poor. The atmosphere is dull. I saw them moving couples out of the way to get coats from cupboards behind their seats (not their coats) . There's nothing redeeming about this place. There are good places to go on Brick Lane! Seriously amazing places. This is not one of them.

wleD0T4ze4NH2ckF2JoWXA.text: I had the chicken tikka blast which apparently won them an award.  If you have any idea or appreciate at all real Indian food, you will not share enjoyment with the taste of Brick lane.  I suppose they've tailored the taste for the English there and I scoff at reviews that use the adjective authentic, unless there's a part of India I'm severely misrepresenting whose favored spice is sugar.It was dumped with sugar.  Almost inedible.  I could barely make out any other redeeming qualities from the disgusting blast of sugar.  No spice heat to speak of, I suppose the chicken itself was cooked well and the naan was decent.  But mostly I just remember the overpowering sauce which seemed like some amateur combo of canned tomato soup sprinkled with some other spice so they could call it curry.  Very disappointed.

pu-vBqIXg5dTZe04mw4ICw.text: Do not go here! The food is mediocre and the service is beyond HORRIBLE. The whole time our server was very rude in too many ways to explain now but the last straw was when another server spilled food on me and didn't even apologize. Will never ever go here or near here again.

E0gDo6yZo9Nz7EVgR58JnA.text: Came here as a single diner and the touts couldn't even be bothered.  Lol.  Fair enough, I was wearing a hoodie and dirty sneakers. Lots and lots of signs and advertising outside the restaurant to have you believe that the food is "award winning/top 10 in London", but falls incredibly short of these statement. I had the following;"Award winning" lamb tikka blast - flavoured ok, not enough meat, and too sweet. Cheese naan (not very cheesy)Poppadums decent but accompanied with gross chutneyMango lassi (can't go too wrong with mango lassi)Total bill came to £24. Could have had much better quality elsewhere. Overall a disappointing experience and won't be going back.

OI9lRjE7fx4ZxrSG0CSiPg.text: I have so much to say about this little strip of Brick Lane!  I've had good and bad, but, well, on to the deets!Aladin is in the middle of a cluster of Indian/Bangladeshi restaurants.  Apparently, this is Prince Charles' favourite.  Apparently, Ainsley Harriot loves this restaurant the most (me: really?  The chef with the massive hands?  server: yes!  Him!).  Apparently, Aladin has won the "best curry 2014" award.  I don't know if any of this is accurate.  But, well, *I* like it, so that counts for something, right?  The reality of Brick Lane is that it's a bit of a gong show, but it's what I like...it's not the best Indian food I've had in London (this feels like treason to commit to type) but it's the best whole dang experience I've had.  It starts when you're out on the street and reps from each of the restaurants come up and try to coax you towards their place.  The "deals" they offer are usually in the range of "20% off!" or "I'll give you X combo deal!" or "rice and naan for free!".  Most recently we snagged the "starter, main, rice or naan for 12 pounds" "deal".  I write deal in quotes not because it wasn't a good food/money investment, but because I think it's a pretty standard offer at the restaurant; it's not like we really negotiated hard.  Sidebar, though: especially if you're in a larger group you can finagle some good "group deals".So, inside it's pretty loud, and busy, and hot.  I'm pretty sure Prince Charles has never hung out on the uncomfortable faux velvet banquette.  Bollywood music pipes in, and you can barely hear it.  Many servers wear Britney Spears-esque headsets.  It's all kind of frenetic, but I find service super polite and attentive.  We ate some lamb kebabs, and bhajis to start (bhajis are just alright here; I think the spicing could be kicked up), but the real star were the mains.  Lamb rogan josh was FABOOSH as was a coconut chicken curry with just the right amount of heat.  Naan were hot and fluffy, and our freebie drinks - mango juice and a flat (wah!) Diet Coke - were totally fine (less so if we had had to pay for them, but a-ok given that they were part of the "freebies" thrown in).On the topic of hydration...IMPORTANT note, booze hounds of Londontown!  It's BYOB.  No corkage fee.  There's some funny deal with an off-license several doors down, where if you show a certain business card you get 20% off your wine.  Honestly, it all felt very cloak-and-dagger to me but it also added to the charm of the whole meal.  By the time I made it back to Aladin with my bottle, wine glasses had been set out and a server whisked my pinot out of my hands to give a v generous pour.  Ai'ght.  GAME ON.Also, another thing I appreciate about Aladin: it's busy, and it's crowded, but I never feel rushed.  We hung out post-meal polishing up the wine and never were hassled to speed it up.  Bill came, hot towels to wash hands, square of orange chocolate...not too bad at all.Yelp note: I can corroborate other reviewers' comments about trying to push extra items / bring items to the table that you never ordered.  Watch out for the popadum, guys!  It comes to the table as an "assumed" order, and it's only when you get your final bill that you realize 1.50 GBP per person has been added to the tally.  This is ok by me - I would have ordered them regardless, and the price is good - but the practice itself is shady and presumptuous.

BfhIi858YTFrKyZjvMqxJA.text: I visited Aladin as part of a food walking tour. We tried three different types of curry along with some naan bread. The service was decent at best and the curry was pretty good. The atmosphere was just alright. Honestly, I feel you can probably get better curry in other places in London, especially with such a large curry choices. Brick lane is a fun place to go. It is a complete mix of shops, curry houses, churches, jewish quarter, art industry, etc. You can find so much on or around this road that it makes it a fun place to spend the afternoon. I would recommend getting curry or Indian food on this strip, but not necessarily here.

photos.caption: Photo of Aladin - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Aladin - London, United Kingdom
